equitorch.nn.functional package

Submodules

equitorch.nn.functional.activations module

equitorch.nn.functional.activations.gating(input: Tensor, gates: Tensor, irreps_info: IrrepsInfo) → Tensor

Equivariant gating mechanism.

Applies element-wise gates to features. This is the functional version of the Gate module.

See Gate for more details on the gating mechanism, including how input and gates are structured and combined.

Parameters:

  • input (torch.Tensor) – Tensor to be gated. Shape (..., irreps.dim, channels).

  • gates (torch.Tensor) – Gating values. Shape depends on how gates are applied (e.g., (..., num_gates, channels) for irrep-wise gating or (..., 1, channels) for global gating).

  • irreps_info (IrrepsInfo) – Contains irreps_info.irrep_index, which maps each component of input’s spherical dimension to an index in gates’ corresponding dimension (the gate dimension).

Returns:

The gated input tensor, shape (..., irreps.dim, channels).

Return type:

torch.Tensor

equitorch.nn.functional.angular module

equitorch.nn.functional.angular.sincos(angle: Tensor, max_m: int, with_ones=True, component_normalize=False)

Prepares the sin/cos tensor for z-rotation.

This is the functional version of the SinCos module. See SinCos for more details.

Parameters:

  • angle (torch.Tensor) – Input angles.

  • max_m (int) – The maximum multiple of the angle to compute.

  • with_ones (bool, optional) – Whether to include the leading 1.0. Defaults to True.

  • component_normalize (bool, optional) – If True, normalizes sin/cos components by \(\sqrt{2}\). Defaults to False.

Returns:

The computed sin/cos tensor.

Return type:

torch.Tensor

equitorch.nn.functional.cutoffs module

equitorch.nn.functional.dropout module

equitorch.nn.functional.dropout.irrep_wise_dropout(input: Tensor, p: float, training: bool, irreps_info: IrrepsInfo) → Tensor

Apply dropout irrep-wise to an input tensor.

This is the functional version of the irrep-wise mode of the Dropout module. See Dropout for more details on the dropout mechanism when irrep_wise=True.

Parameters:

  • input (torch.Tensor) – Input tensor of shape (..., irreps_dim, channels).

  • p (float) – Probability of an element to be zeroed.

  • training (bool) – Apply dropout if True.

  • irreps_info (IrrepsInfo) – Contains irreps structure information, such as irreps_info.irrep_index to map components of input to their respective irrep instances, and irreps_info.num_irreps. Must not be None.

Returns:

Output tensor with dropout applied, of the same shape as input.

Return type:

torch.Tensor

equitorch.nn.functional.linears module

class equitorch.nn.functional.linears.TensorProductU1UDummy(*args, **kwargs)

Bases: Function

static backward(ctx, grad_output, grad_inter)

Define a formula for differentiating the operation with backward mode automatic differentiation.

This function is to be overridden by all subclasses. (Defining this function is equivalent to defining the vjp function.)

It must accept a context ctx as the first argument, followed by as many outputs as the forward() returned (None will be passed in for non tensor outputs of the forward function), and it should return as many tensors, as there were inputs to forward(). Each argument is the gradient w.r.t the given output, and each returned value should be the gradient w.r.t. the corresponding input. If an input is not a Tensor or is a Tensor not requiring grads, you can just pass None as a gradient for that input.

The context can be used to retrieve tensors saved during the forward pass. It also has an attribute ctx.needs_input_grad as a tuple of booleans representing whether each input needs gradient. E.g., backward() will have ctx.needs_input_grad[0] = True if the first input to forward() needs gradient computed w.r.t. the output.

equitorch.nn.functional.linears.tensor_product_u1u(input1: Tensor, input2: Tensor, weight: Tensor, tp_info_forward: TensorProductInfo, tp_info_backward1: TensorProductInfo = None, tp_info_backward2: TensorProductInfo = None)

equitorch.nn.functional.norm module

class equitorch.nn.functional.norm.SquaredNorm(*args, **kwargs)

Bases: Function

Computes the squared L2 norm for each irrep block in an input tensor. Output_k = sum_{i in irrep_k} (input_i^2) Optionally scales the output by 1/sqrt(dim_irrep_k).

static backward(ctx, grad_output: Tensor)

Define a formula for differentiating the operation with backward mode automatic differentiation.

This function is to be overridden by all subclasses. (Defining this function is equivalent to defining the vjp function.)

It must accept a context ctx as the first argument, followed by as many outputs as the forward() returned (None will be passed in for non tensor outputs of the forward function), and it should return as many tensors, as there were inputs to forward(). Each argument is the gradient w.r.t the given output, and each returned value should be the gradient w.r.t. the corresponding input. If an input is not a Tensor or is a Tensor not requiring grads, you can just pass None as a gradient for that input.

The context can be used to retrieve tensors saved during the forward pass. It also has an attribute ctx.needs_input_grad as a tuple of booleans representing whether each input needs gradient. E.g., backward() will have ctx.needs_input_grad[0] = True if the first input to forward() needs gradient computed w.r.t. the output.

equitorch.nn.functional.norm.squared_norm(input_tensor: Tensor, irreps_info: IrrepsInfo, scaled: bool = True) → Tensor
class equitorch.nn.functional.norm.Norm(*args, **kwargs)

Bases: Function

Computes the L2 norm for each irrep block in an input tensor. Output_k = sqrt(sum_{i in irrep_k} (input_i^2)) Optionally scales the output by 1/sqrt(dim_irrep_k). Gradient at zero vector is zero.

Hessian at zero vector is not supported (returns nan).

static backward(ctx, grad_output: Tensor)

Define a formula for differentiating the operation with backward mode automatic differentiation.

This function is to be overridden by all subclasses. (Defining this function is equivalent to defining the vjp function.)

It must accept a context ctx as the first argument, followed by as many outputs as the forward() returned (None will be passed in for non tensor outputs of the forward function), and it should return as many tensors, as there were inputs to forward(). Each argument is the gradient w.r.t the given output, and each returned value should be the gradient w.r.t. the corresponding input. If an input is not a Tensor or is a Tensor not requiring grads, you can just pass None as a gradient for that input.

The context can be used to retrieve tensors saved during the forward pass. It also has an attribute ctx.needs_input_grad as a tuple of booleans representing whether each input needs gradient. E.g., backward() will have ctx.needs_input_grad[0] = True if the first input to forward() needs gradient computed w.r.t. the output.

equitorch.nn.functional.norm.norm(input_tensor: Tensor, irreps_info: IrrepsInfo, scaled: bool = True)
class equitorch.nn.functional.norm.ChannelMeanSquaredNorm(*args, **kwargs)

Bases: Function

Computes the mean of squared L2 norms over channels for each irrep block. Output_k = (1/C) * sum_c ( sum_{i in irrep_k} (input_i_c^2) ) Optionally scales the output by 1/dim_irrep_k.

equitorch.nn.functional.norm.channel_mean_squared_norm(input_tensor: Tensor, irreps_info: IrrepsInfo, scaled: bool = True) → Tensor
class equitorch.nn.functional.norm.BatchMeanSquaredNorm(*args, **kwargs)

Bases: Function

Computes the mean of squared L2 norms over the batch dimension for each irrep block and channel. Output_ic = (1/N) * sum_n ( sum_{m in irrep_i} (input_n(im)c^2) ) Optionally scales the output by 1/dim_irrep_i.

static backward(ctx, grad_output: Tensor)

Define a formula for differentiating the operation with backward mode automatic differentiation.

This function is to be overridden by all subclasses. (Defining this function is equivalent to defining the vjp function.)

It must accept a context ctx as the first argument, followed by as many outputs as the forward() returned (None will be passed in for non tensor outputs of the forward function), and it should return as many tensors, as there were inputs to forward(). Each argument is the gradient w.r.t the given output, and each returned value should be the gradient w.r.t. the corresponding input. If an input is not a Tensor or is a Tensor not requiring grads, you can just pass None as a gradient for that input.

The context can be used to retrieve tensors saved during the forward pass. It also has an attribute ctx.needs_input_grad as a tuple of booleans representing whether each input needs gradient. E.g., backward() will have ctx.needs_input_grad[0] = True if the first input to forward() needs gradient computed w.r.t. the output.

equitorch.nn.functional.norm.batch_mean_squared_norm(input_tensor: Tensor, irreps_info: IrrepsInfo, scaled: bool = True)

equitorch.nn.functional.normalization module

equitorch.nn.functional.normalization.batch_rms_norm(input: Tensor, running_squared_norm: Tensor, irreps_info: IrrepsInfo, weight: Tensor = None, scaled: bool = True, training: bool = False, momentum: float = 0.1, eps: float = 1e-05) → Tensor

Applies Batch RMS Normalization for equivariant features.

Parameters:

  • input (Tensor) – Input tensor of shape (N, irreps_dim, C).

  • running_squared_norm (Tensor) – Running average of squared norms, shape (num_irreps, C). Modified in-place if training is True.

  • irreps_info (IrrepsInfo) – Contains irreps structure information.

  • weight (Tensor, optional) – Learnable scaling factor gamma_ic, shape (num_irreps, C). Defaults to None (no scaling).

  • scaled (bool, optional) – If True, the internal squared_norm calculation divides by the dimension of the irrep (D_i). Defaults to True.

  • training (bool, optional) – If True, uses current batch statistics for normalization and updates running_squared_norm. Otherwise, uses running_squared_norm. Defaults to False.

  • momentum (float, optional) – Momentum for updating running_squared_norm. Defaults to 0.1.

  • eps (float, optional) – Epsilon for numerical stability. Defaults to 1e-05.

Returns:

Normalized output tensor of the same shape as input.

Return type:

Tensor

equitorch.nn.functional.normalization.layer_rms_norm(input_tensor: Tensor, irreps_info: IrrepsInfo, weight: Tensor = None, scaled: bool = True, eps: float = 1e-05) → Tensor

Applies Layer Root Mean Square Normalization for equivariant features.

Parameters:

  • input_tensor (Tensor) – Input tensor of shape (N, irreps_dim, C).

  • irreps_info (IrrepsInfo) – Contains irreps structure information.

  • weight (Tensor, optional) – Learnable scaling factor gamma_ic, shape (num_irreps, C). Defaults to None (no scaling).

  • scaled (bool, optional) – If True, the statistics calculation considers the norm to be scaled by 1/D_i. Defaults to True.

  • eps (float, optional) – Epsilon for numerical stability. Defaults to 1e-05.

Returns:

Normalized output tensor of the same shape as input.

Return type:

Tensor

equitorch.nn.functional.rotations module

equitorch.nn.functional.rotations.angles_to_matrix(alpha: Tensor | None = None, beta: Tensor | None = None, gamma: Tensor | None = None) → Tensor

Convert Euler angles (ZYZ convention) to rotation matrices.

Parameters:

  • alpha – First rotation angle about z-axis (radians)

  • beta – Second rotation angle about y-axis (radians)

  • gamma – Third rotation angle about z-axis (radians)

Returns:

Rotation matrices of shape (…, 3, 3)

equitorch.nn.functional.sparse_product module

class equitorch.nn.functional.sparse_product.SparseMul(*args, **kwargs)

Bases: Function

static backward(ctx, grad_output)

Define a formula for differentiating the operation with backward mode automatic differentiation.

This function is to be overridden by all subclasses. (Defining this function is equivalent to defining the vjp function.)

It must accept a context ctx as the first argument, followed by as many outputs as the forward() returned (None will be passed in for non tensor outputs of the forward function), and it should return as many tensors, as there were inputs to forward(). Each argument is the gradient w.r.t the given output, and each returned value should be the gradient w.r.t. the corresponding input. If an input is not a Tensor or is a Tensor not requiring grads, you can just pass None as a gradient for that input.

The context can be used to retrieve tensors saved during the forward pass. It also has an attribute ctx.needs_input_grad as a tuple of booleans representing whether each input needs gradient. E.g., backward() will have ctx.needs_input_grad[0] = True if the first input to forward() needs gradient computed w.r.t. the output.

equitorch.nn.functional.sparse_product.sparse_mul(input1: Tensor, input2: Tensor, info_fwd: SparseProductInfo, info_bwd1: SparseProductInfo | None = None, info_bwd2: SparseProductInfo | None = None, out_accumulated: bool = False) → Tensor

Computes sparse element-wise multiplication using indexed operations.

This function performs an element-wise product of two input tensors, input1 and input2, based on the indexing and scaling information provided in info_fwd. The operation is “sparse” in the sense that it uses predefined indexing schemes to select elements for multiplication, rather than a dense matrix multiplication.

The backward pass information can be optionally provided via info_bwd1 and info_bwd2 for custom gradient calculations if needed.

Parameters:

  • input1 (torch.Tensor) – The first input tensor.

  • input2 (torch.Tensor) – The second input tensor.

  • info_fwd (SparseProductInfo) – Contains scaling factors, indices for input1 and input2, output segmentation, gather indices, and output indices for the forward pass.

  • info_bwd1 (SparseProductInfo, optional) – Information for the backward pass with respect to input1. Defaults to None.

  • info_bwd2 (SparseProductInfo, optional) – Information for the backward pass with respect to input2. Defaults to None.

  • out_accumulated (bool, optional) – If True, the output is accumulated into an existing tensor (not fully supported by all underlying ops, behavior might vary). Defaults to False.

Returns:

The result of the sparse element-wise multiplication.

Return type:

torch.Tensor

class equitorch.nn.functional.sparse_product.SparseOuter(*args, **kwargs)

Bases: Function

static backward(ctx, grad_output: Tensor)

Define a formula for differentiating the operation with backward mode automatic differentiation.

This function is to be overridden by all subclasses. (Defining this function is equivalent to defining the vjp function.)

It must accept a context ctx as the first argument, followed by as many outputs as the forward() returned (None will be passed in for non tensor outputs of the forward function), and it should return as many tensors, as there were inputs to forward(). Each argument is the gradient w.r.t the given output, and each returned value should be the gradient w.r.t. the corresponding input. If an input is not a Tensor or is a Tensor not requiring grads, you can just pass None as a gradient for that input.

The context can be used to retrieve tensors saved during the forward pass. It also has an attribute ctx.needs_input_grad as a tuple of booleans representing whether each input needs gradient. E.g., backward() will have ctx.needs_input_grad[0] = True if the first input to forward() needs gradient computed w.r.t. the output.

equitorch.nn.functional.sparse_product.sparse_outer(input1: Tensor, input2: Tensor, info_fwd: SparseProductInfo, info_bwd1: SparseProductInfo | None = None, info_bwd2: SparseProductInfo | None = None, out_accumulated: bool = False) → Tensor

Computes sparse outer product using indexed operations.

This function performs an outer product of input1 and input2 based on the indexing and scaling information in info_fwd. The result is typically a higher-rank tensor.

Parameters:

  • input1 (torch.Tensor) – The first input tensor (often a vector).

  • input2 (torch.Tensor) – The second input tensor (often a vector).

  • info_fwd (SparseProductInfo) – Information for the forward pass.

  • info_bwd1 (SparseProductInfo, optional) – Information for the backward pass w.r.t. input1.

  • info_bwd2 (SparseProductInfo, optional) – Information for the backward pass w.r.t. input2.

  • out_accumulated (bool, optional) – If True, accumulate to output. Defaults to False.

Returns:

The result of the sparse outer product.

Return type:

torch.Tensor

class equitorch.nn.functional.sparse_product.SparseInner(*args, **kwargs)

Bases: Function

static backward(ctx, grad_output: Tensor)

Define a formula for differentiating the operation with backward mode automatic differentiation.

This function is to be overridden by all subclasses. (Defining this function is equivalent to defining the vjp function.)

It must accept a context ctx as the first argument, followed by as many outputs as the forward() returned (None will be passed in for non tensor outputs of the forward function), and it should return as many tensors, as there were inputs to forward(). Each argument is the gradient w.r.t the given output, and each returned value should be the gradient w.r.t. the corresponding input. If an input is not a Tensor or is a Tensor not requiring grads, you can just pass None as a gradient for that input.

The context can be used to retrieve tensors saved during the forward pass. It also has an attribute ctx.needs_input_grad as a tuple of booleans representing whether each input needs gradient. E.g., backward() will have ctx.needs_input_grad[0] = True if the first input to forward() needs gradient computed w.r.t. the output.

equitorch.nn.functional.sparse_product.sparse_inner(input1: Tensor, input2: Tensor, info_fwd: SparseProductInfo, info_bwd1: SparseProductInfo | None = None, info_bwd2: SparseProductInfo | None = None, out_accumulated: bool = False) → Tensor

Computes sparse inner product using indexed operations.

This function performs an inner product (dot product) between input1 and input2 based on the indexing and scaling information in info_fwd. The result is typically a scalar or a lower-rank tensor.

Parameters:

  • input1 (torch.Tensor) – The first input tensor.

  • input2 (torch.Tensor) – The second input tensor.

  • info_fwd (SparseProductInfo) – Information for the forward pass.

  • info_bwd1 (SparseProductInfo, optional) – Information for the backward pass w.r.t. input1.

  • info_bwd2 (SparseProductInfo, optional) – Information for the backward pass w.r.t. input2.

  • out_accumulated (bool, optional) – If True, accumulate to output. Defaults to False.

Returns:

The result of the sparse inner product.

Return type:

torch.Tensor

class equitorch.nn.functional.sparse_product.SparseVecMat(*args, **kwargs)

Bases: Function

static backward(ctx, grad_output: Tensor)

Define a formula for differentiating the operation with backward mode automatic differentiation.

This function is to be overridden by all subclasses. (Defining this function is equivalent to defining the vjp function.)

It must accept a context ctx as the first argument, followed by as many outputs as the forward() returned (None will be passed in for non tensor outputs of the forward function), and it should return as many tensors, as there were inputs to forward(). Each argument is the gradient w.r.t the given output, and each returned value should be the gradient w.r.t. the corresponding input. If an input is not a Tensor or is a Tensor not requiring grads, you can just pass None as a gradient for that input.

The context can be used to retrieve tensors saved during the forward pass. It also has an attribute ctx.needs_input_grad as a tuple of booleans representing whether each input needs gradient. E.g., backward() will have ctx.needs_input_grad[0] = True if the first input to forward() needs gradient computed w.r.t. the output.

equitorch.nn.functional.sphericals module

equitorch.nn.functional.sphericals.spherical_harmonics(input: Tensor, l_max: int, dim: int = -1, integral_normalize: bool = False)
equitorch.nn.functional.sphericals.xyz_to_spherical(xyz: Tensor, normalize_input: bool = True, with_r: bool = False, eps: float = 1e-14, dim: int = -1) → tuple[Tensor, ...] | Tensor

Computes spherical coordinates (r, theta, phi) from Cartesian coordinates (x, y, z).

Parameters:

  • xyz (Tensor) – Input tensor with Cartesian coordinates. Assumed to have shape (…, 3). The last dimension (specified by dim) should contain x, y, z.

  • normalize_input (bool, optional) – If True, normalizes the input xyz vector before computing angles, effectively setting r=1 for angle calculation. The returned r will still be the original magnitude unless with_r is False and normalized is True. Defaults to True.

  • with_r (bool, optional) – If True, returns r along with theta and phi. If False, returns only theta and phi. Defaults to False.

  • eps (float, optional) – Small epsilon value to avoid division by zero or acos/atan2 instabilities. Defaults to 1e-14.

  • dim (int, optional) – The dimension along which x, y, z are stored. Defaults to -1.

Returns:

If with_r is True: (theta, phi, r) If with_r is False: (theta, phi) - theta: Polar angle (inclination) from z-axis. Range [0, pi]. Shape (…) - phi: Azimuthal angle in x-y plane from x-axis. Range [-pi, pi]. Shape (…) - r: Radius. Shape (…)

Return type:

tuple[Tensor, …] | Tensor

equitorch.nn.functional.sphericals.spherical_to_xyz(theta: Tensor, phi: Tensor, r: Tensor | None = None, dim: int = -1) → Tensor

Computes Cartesian coordinates (x, y, z) from spherical coordinates (theta, phi, r).

Parameters:

  • theta (Tensor) – Polar angle (inclination) from z-axis. Shape (…).

  • phi (Tensor) – Azimuthal angle in x-y plane from x-axis. Shape (…).

  • r (Optional[Tensor], optional) – Radius. If None, assumed to be 1. Shape (…). Defaults to None.

  • dim (int, optional) – The dimension along which the output x, y, z will be stacked. Defaults to -1.

Returns:

Output tensor with Cartesian coordinates (x, y, z). Shape (…, 3).

Return type:

Tensor

equitorch.nn.functional.sphericals.xyz_to_sincos(xyz: Tensor, max_m: int, normalize_input: bool = True, component_normalize: bool = False, eps: float = 1e-14, dim: int = -1) → Tensor

Computes the sin/cos embedding of the azimuthal angle (phi) derived from Cartesian coordinates (x, y, z).

The sin/cos embedding is typically of the form: [1.0, sin(phi), cos(phi), sin(2*phi), cos(2*phi), …, sin(max_m*phi), cos(max_m*phi)]

Parameters:

  • xyz (Tensor) – Input tensor with Cartesian coordinates. Shape (…, 3).

  • max_m (int) – The maximum multiple of the angle phi to compute sin/cos for.

  • normalize_input (bool, optional) – If True, normalizes xyz before extracting angles. Defaults to True.

  • eps (float, optional) – Small epsilon for numerical stability in xyz_to_spherical. Defaults to 1e-14.

  • dim (int, optional) – Dimension of Cartesian coordinates in xyz. Defaults to -1.

  • component_normalize (bool) – If true, multiply sin and cos by sqrt(2), such that the expectation of each element is 1.

Returns:

The sin/cos embedding of the phi angle. Shape (…, 1 + 2 * max_m).

Return type:

Tensor

equitorch.nn.functional.tensor_products module

class equitorch.nn.functional.tensor_products.TensorProductUUUDummy(*args, **kwargs)

Bases: Function

static backward(ctx, grad_output, grad_inter)

Define a formula for differentiating the operation with backward mode automatic differentiation.

This function is to be overridden by all subclasses. (Defining this function is equivalent to defining the vjp function.)

It must accept a context ctx as the first argument, followed by as many outputs as the forward() returned (None will be passed in for non tensor outputs of the forward function), and it should return as many tensors, as there were inputs to forward(). Each argument is the gradient w.r.t the given output, and each returned value should be the gradient w.r.t. the corresponding input. If an input is not a Tensor or is a Tensor not requiring grads, you can just pass None as a gradient for that input.

The context can be used to retrieve tensors saved during the forward pass. It also has an attribute ctx.needs_input_grad as a tuple of booleans representing whether each input needs gradient. E.g., backward() will have ctx.needs_input_grad[0] = True if the first input to forward() needs gradient computed w.r.t. the output.

equitorch.nn.functional.wigner_d module

equitorch.nn.functional.wigner_d.sparse_wigner_rotation(input: Tensor, sincos_alpha: Tensor | None, sincos_beta: Tensor | None, sincos_gamma: Tensor | None, info: WignerRotationInfo) → Tensor

Applies sparse Wigner D-matrix rotation \(D(lpha, eta, \gamma) = D_z(lpha)D_y(eta)D_z(\gamma)\).

Functional version of SparseWignerRotation. See the class for more details.

  • input (torch.Tensor) – Input features.

  • sincos_alpha (Optional[torch.Tensor]) – Precomputed sin/cos of Euler angle \(lpha\).

  • sincos_beta (Optional[torch.Tensor]) – Precomputed sin/cos of Euler angle \(eta\).

  • sincos_gamma (Optional[torch.Tensor]) – Precomputed sin/cos of Euler angle \(\gamma\).

  • info (WignerRotationInfo) – Precomputed sparse rotation information.

Returns:

Rotated features.

Return type:

equitorch.nn.functional.wigner_d.wigner_d_matrix(eye: Tensor, alpha: Tensor | None = None, beta: Tensor | None = None, gamma: Tensor | None = None, sincos_alpha: Tensor | None = None, sincos_beta: Tensor | None = None, sincos_gamma: Tensor | None = None, info: WignerRotationInfo | None = None) → Tensor

Parameters:

  • eye (Tensor) – Identity matrix of shape (dim, dim). Device and dtype are inferred.

  • alpha (Optional[Tensor]) – Alpha Euler angle.

  • beta (Optional[Tensor]) – Beta Euler angle.

  • gamma (Optional[Tensor]) – Gamma Euler angle.

  • sincos_alpha (Optional[Tensor]) – Precomputed sin/cos for alpha angle.

  • sincos_beta (Optional[Tensor]) – Precomputed sin/cos for beta angle.

  • sincos_gamma (Optional[Tensor]) – Precomputed sin/cos for gamma angle.

  • info (WignerRotationInfo) – Precomputed sparse rotation info.

or (dim, dim) if angles are not batched.

equitorch.nn.functional.wigner_d.align_to_z_wigner_d(eye: Tensor, xyz: Tensor, max_m: int, info: WignerRotationInfo, normalized: bool = True, eps: float = 1e-14) → Tensor

Computes Wigner D-matrix \(D(R_{align})\) that rotates vector \(\vec{v}\) to z-axis.

Functional version of AlignToZWignerD.

See the class for more details.

The rotation \(R_{align}\) is \((0, -\theta, -\phi)\) where \(\theta, \phi\) are polar and azimuthal angles of \(\vec{v}\).

Parameters:

  • eye (torch.Tensor) – Identity matrix of shape (dim, dim).

  • xyz (torch.Tensor) – Input Cartesian coordinates, shape (..., 3).

  • max_m (int) – Maximum m value for sincos calculation, derived from irreps.

  • info (WignerRotationInfo) – Precomputed sparse rotation info for the irreps.

  • normalized (bool, optional) – Whether xyz is already normalized. Defaults to True.

  • eps (float, optional) – Epsilon for numerical stability. Defaults to 1e-14.

Returns:

Dense Wigner D-matrix for alignment, shape (..., dim, dim).

Return type:

torch.Tensor

Module contents

Provides functional implementations of equivariant neural network operations.

equitorch.nn.functional.tensor_product_u1u(input1: Tensor, input2: Tensor, weight: Tensor, tp_info_forward: TensorProductInfo, tp_info_backward1: TensorProductInfo = None, tp_info_backward2: TensorProductInfo = None)
equitorch.nn.functional.so3_linear_uu(input1: Tensor, input2: Tensor, weight: Tensor, tp_info_forward: TensorProductInfo, tp_info_backward1: TensorProductInfo = None, tp_info_backward2: TensorProductInfo = None)
equitorch.nn.functional.tensor_product_1uu(input1: Tensor, input2: Tensor, weight: Tensor, tp_info_forward: TensorProductInfo, tp_info_backward1: TensorProductInfo = None, tp_info_backward2: TensorProductInfo = None)
equitorch.nn.functional.tensor_product_uu1(input1: Tensor, input2: Tensor, weight: Tensor, tp_info_forward: TensorProductInfo, tp_info_backward1: TensorProductInfo = None, tp_info_backward2: TensorProductInfo = None)
equitorch.nn.functional.tensor_product_u1v(input1: Tensor, input2: Tensor, weight: Tensor, tp_info_forward: TensorProductInfo, tp_info_backward1: TensorProductInfo = None, tp_info_backward2: TensorProductInfo = None)
equitorch.nn.functional.so3_linear_uv(input1: Tensor, input2: Tensor, weight: Tensor, tp_info_forward: TensorProductInfo, tp_info_backward1: TensorProductInfo = None, tp_info_backward2: TensorProductInfo = None)
equitorch.nn.functional.tensor_product_1vu(input1: Tensor, input2: Tensor, weight: Tensor, tp_info_forward: TensorProductInfo, tp_info_backward1: TensorProductInfo, tp_info_backward2: TensorProductInfo)
equitorch.nn.functional.tensor_product_vu1(input1: Tensor, input2: Tensor, weight: Tensor, tp_info_forward: TensorProductInfo, tp_info_backward1: TensorProductInfo, tp_info_backward2: TensorProductInfo)
equitorch.nn.functional.irrep_wise_linear(*args, **kwargs)
equitorch.nn.functional.irreps_linear(*args, **kwargs)
equitorch.nn.functional.so2_linear_uu(input1: Tensor, input2: Tensor, info_fwd: SparseProductInfo, info_bwd1: SparseProductInfo | None = None, info_bwd2: SparseProductInfo | None = None, out_accumulated: bool = False) → Tensor

Computes sparse element-wise multiplication using indexed operations.

This function performs an element-wise product of two input tensors, input1 and input2, based on the indexing and scaling information provided in info_fwd. The operation is “sparse” in the sense that it uses predefined indexing schemes to select elements for multiplication, rather than a dense matrix multiplication.

The backward pass information can be optionally provided via info_bwd1 and info_bwd2 for custom gradient calculations if needed.

Parameters:

  • input1 (torch.Tensor) – The first input tensor.

  • input2 (torch.Tensor) – The second input tensor.

  • info_fwd (SparseProductInfo) – Contains scaling factors, indices for input1 and input2, output segmentation, gather indices, and output indices for the forward pass.

  • info_bwd1 (SparseProductInfo, optional) – Information for the backward pass with respect to input1. Defaults to None.

  • info_bwd2 (SparseProductInfo, optional) – Information for the backward pass with respect to input2. Defaults to None.

  • out_accumulated (bool, optional) – If True, the output is accumulated into an existing tensor (not fully supported by all underlying ops, behavior might vary). Defaults to False.

Returns:

The result of the sparse element-wise multiplication.

Return type:

torch.Tensor

equitorch.nn.functional.so2_linear_uv(input1: Tensor, input2: Tensor, info_fwd: SparseProductInfo, info_bwd1: SparseProductInfo | None = None, info_bwd2: SparseProductInfo | None = None, out_accumulated: bool = False) → Tensor

Computes sparse vector-matrix multiplication using indexed operations.

Multiplies a vector (input1) by a matrix (input2) based on info_fwd.

Parameters:

  • input1 (torch.Tensor) – The input vector.

  • input2 (torch.Tensor) – The input matrix.

  • info_fwd (SparseProductInfo) – Information for the forward pass.

  • info_bwd1 (SparseProductInfo, optional) – Information for the backward pass w.r.t. input1.

  • info_bwd2 (SparseProductInfo, optional) – Information for the backward pass w.r.t. input2.

  • out_accumulated (bool, optional) – If True, accumulate to output. Defaults to False.

Returns:

The result of the sparse vector-matrix multiplication.

Return type:

torch.Tensor

equitorch.nn.functional.spherical_harmonics(input: Tensor, l_max: int, dim: int = -1, integral_normalize: bool = False)
equitorch.nn.functional.xyz_to_spherical(xyz: Tensor, normalize_input: bool = True, with_r: bool = False, eps: float = 1e-14, dim: int = -1) → tuple[Tensor, ...] | Tensor

Computes spherical coordinates (r, theta, phi) from Cartesian coordinates (x, y, z).

Parameters:

  • xyz (Tensor) – Input tensor with Cartesian coordinates. Assumed to have shape (…, 3). The last dimension (specified by dim) should contain x, y, z.

  • normalize_input (bool, optional) – If True, normalizes the input xyz vector before computing angles, effectively setting r=1 for angle calculation. The returned r will still be the original magnitude unless with_r is False and normalized is True. Defaults to True.

  • with_r (bool, optional) – If True, returns r along with theta and phi. If False, returns only theta and phi. Defaults to False.

  • eps (float, optional) – Small epsilon value to avoid division by zero or acos/atan2 instabilities. Defaults to 1e-14.

  • dim (int, optional) – The dimension along which x, y, z are stored. Defaults to -1.

Returns:

If with_r is True: (theta, phi, r) If with_r is False: (theta, phi) - theta: Polar angle (inclination) from z-axis. Range [0, pi]. Shape (…) - phi: Azimuthal angle in x-y plane from x-axis. Range [-pi, pi]. Shape (…) - r: Radius. Shape (…)

Return type:

tuple[Tensor, …] | Tensor

equitorch.nn.functional.spherical_to_xyz(theta: Tensor, phi: Tensor, r: Tensor | None = None, dim: int = -1) → Tensor

Computes Cartesian coordinates (x, y, z) from spherical coordinates (theta, phi, r).

Parameters:

  • theta (Tensor) – Polar angle (inclination) from z-axis. Shape (…).

  • phi (Tensor) – Azimuthal angle in x-y plane from x-axis. Shape (…).

  • r (Optional[Tensor], optional) – Radius. If None, assumed to be 1. Shape (…). Defaults to None.

  • dim (int, optional) – The dimension along which the output x, y, z will be stacked. Defaults to -1.

Returns:

Output tensor with Cartesian coordinates (x, y, z). Shape (…, 3).

Return type:

Tensor

equitorch.nn.functional.xyz_to_sincos(xyz: Tensor, max_m: int, normalize_input: bool = True, component_normalize: bool = False, eps: float = 1e-14, dim: int = -1) → Tensor

Computes the sin/cos embedding of the azimuthal angle (phi) derived from Cartesian coordinates (x, y, z).

The sin/cos embedding is typically of the form: [1.0, sin(phi), cos(phi), sin(2*phi), cos(2*phi), …, sin(max_m*phi), cos(max_m*phi)]

Parameters:

  • xyz (Tensor) – Input tensor with Cartesian coordinates. Shape (…, 3).

  • max_m (int) – The maximum multiple of the angle phi to compute sin/cos for.

  • normalize_input (bool, optional) – If True, normalizes xyz before extracting angles. Defaults to True.

  • eps (float, optional) – Small epsilon for numerical stability in xyz_to_spherical. Defaults to 1e-14.

  • dim (int, optional) – Dimension of Cartesian coordinates in xyz. Defaults to -1.

  • component_normalize (bool) – If true, multiply sin and cos by sqrt(2), such that the expectation of each element is 1.

Returns:

The sin/cos embedding of the phi angle. Shape (…, 1 + 2 * max_m).

Return type:

Tensor

equitorch.nn.functional.batch_rms_norm(input: Tensor, running_squared_norm: Tensor, irreps_info: IrrepsInfo, weight: Tensor = None, scaled: bool = True, training: bool = False, momentum: float = 0.1, eps: float = 1e-05) → Tensor

Applies Batch RMS Normalization for equivariant features.

Parameters:

  • input (Tensor) – Input tensor of shape (N, irreps_dim, C).

  • running_squared_norm (Tensor) – Running average of squared norms, shape (num_irreps, C). Modified in-place if training is True.

  • irreps_info (IrrepsInfo) – Contains irreps structure information.

  • weight (Tensor, optional) – Learnable scaling factor gamma_ic, shape (num_irreps, C). Defaults to None (no scaling).

  • scaled (bool, optional) – If True, the internal squared_norm calculation divides by the dimension of the irrep (D_i). Defaults to True.

  • training (bool, optional) – If True, uses current batch statistics for normalization and updates running_squared_norm. Otherwise, uses running_squared_norm. Defaults to False.

  • momentum (float, optional) – Momentum for updating running_squared_norm. Defaults to 0.1.

  • eps (float, optional) – Epsilon for numerical stability. Defaults to 1e-05.

Returns:

Normalized output tensor of the same shape as input.

Return type:

Tensor

equitorch.nn.functional.layer_rms_norm(input_tensor: Tensor, irreps_info: IrrepsInfo, weight: Tensor = None, scaled: bool = True, eps: float = 1e-05) → Tensor

Applies Layer Root Mean Square Normalization for equivariant features.

Parameters:

  • input_tensor (Tensor) – Input tensor of shape (N, irreps_dim, C).

  • irreps_info (IrrepsInfo) – Contains irreps structure information.

  • weight (Tensor, optional) – Learnable scaling factor gamma_ic, shape (num_irreps, C). Defaults to None (no scaling).

  • scaled (bool, optional) – If True, the statistics calculation considers the norm to be scaled by 1/D_i. Defaults to True.

  • eps (float, optional) – Epsilon for numerical stability. Defaults to 1e-05.

Returns:

Normalized output tensor of the same shape as input.

Return type:

Tensor

equitorch.nn.functional.sparse_scale(input: Tensor, info_fwd: SparseScaleInfo, info_bwd: SparseScaleInfo | None = None) → Tensor
equitorch.nn.functional.tensor_product_uuu(input1: Tensor, input2: Tensor, weight: Tensor, tp_info_forward: TensorProductInfo, tp_info_backward1: TensorProductInfo = None, tp_info_backward2: TensorProductInfo = None)
equitorch.nn.functional.tensor_product_uvw(input1: Tensor, input2: Tensor, weight: Tensor, tp_info_forward: TensorProductInfo, tp_info_backward1: TensorProductInfo = None, tp_info_backward2: TensorProductInfo = None)
equitorch.nn.functional.tensor_dot_uu(*args, **kwargs)
equitorch.nn.functional.tensor_dot_uv(*args, **kwargs)
equitorch.nn.functional.sparse_mul(input1: Tensor, input2: Tensor, info_fwd: SparseProductInfo, info_bwd1: SparseProductInfo | None = None, info_bwd2: SparseProductInfo | None = None, out_accumulated: bool = False) → Tensor

Computes sparse element-wise multiplication using indexed operations.

This function performs an element-wise product of two input tensors, input1 and input2, based on the indexing and scaling information provided in info_fwd. The operation is “sparse” in the sense that it uses predefined indexing schemes to select elements for multiplication, rather than a dense matrix multiplication.

The backward pass information can be optionally provided via info_bwd1 and info_bwd2 for custom gradient calculations if needed.

Parameters:

  • input1 (torch.Tensor) – The first input tensor.

  • input2 (torch.Tensor) – The second input tensor.

  • info_fwd (SparseProductInfo) – Contains scaling factors, indices for input1 and input2, output segmentation, gather indices, and output indices for the forward pass.

  • info_bwd1 (SparseProductInfo, optional) – Information for the backward pass with respect to input1. Defaults to None.

  • info_bwd2 (SparseProductInfo, optional) – Information for the backward pass with respect to input2. Defaults to None.

  • out_accumulated (bool, optional) – If True, the output is accumulated into an existing tensor (not fully supported by all underlying ops, behavior might vary). Defaults to False.

Returns:

The result of the sparse element-wise multiplication.

Return type:

torch.Tensor

equitorch.nn.functional.sparse_outer(input1: Tensor, input2: Tensor, info_fwd: SparseProductInfo, info_bwd1: SparseProductInfo | None = None, info_bwd2: SparseProductInfo | None = None, out_accumulated: bool = False) → Tensor

Computes sparse outer product using indexed operations.

This function performs an outer product of input1 and input2 based on the indexing and scaling information in info_fwd. The result is typically a higher-rank tensor.

Parameters:

  • input1 (torch.Tensor) – The first input tensor (often a vector).

  • input2 (torch.Tensor) – The second input tensor (often a vector).

  • info_fwd (SparseProductInfo) – Information for the forward pass.

  • info_bwd1 (SparseProductInfo, optional) – Information for the backward pass w.r.t. input1.

  • info_bwd2 (SparseProductInfo, optional) – Information for the backward pass w.r.t. input2.

  • out_accumulated (bool, optional) – If True, accumulate to output. Defaults to False.

Returns:

The result of the sparse outer product.

Return type:

torch.Tensor

equitorch.nn.functional.sparse_inner(input1: Tensor, input2: Tensor, info_fwd: SparseProductInfo, info_bwd1: SparseProductInfo | None = None, info_bwd2: SparseProductInfo | None = None, out_accumulated: bool = False) → Tensor

Computes sparse inner product using indexed operations.

This function performs an inner product (dot product) between input1 and input2 based on the indexing and scaling information in info_fwd. The result is typically a scalar or a lower-rank tensor.

Parameters:

  • input1 (torch.Tensor) – The first input tensor.

  • input2 (torch.Tensor) – The second input tensor.

  • info_fwd (SparseProductInfo) – Information for the forward pass.

  • info_bwd1 (SparseProductInfo, optional) – Information for the backward pass w.r.t. input1.

  • info_bwd2 (SparseProductInfo, optional) – Information for the backward pass w.r.t. input2.

  • out_accumulated (bool, optional) – If True, accumulate to output. Defaults to False.

Returns:

The result of the sparse inner product.

Return type:

torch.Tensor

Applies sparse Wigner D-matrix rotation \(D(lpha, eta, \gamma) = D_z(lpha)D_y(eta)D_z(\gamma)\).

  • sincos_beta (Optional[torch.Tensor]) – Precomputed sin/cos of Euler angle \(eta\).

  • sincos_gamma (Optional[torch.Tensor]) – Precomputed sin/cos of Euler angle \(\gamma\).

  • info (WignerRotationInfo) – Precomputed sparse rotation information.

Computes the dense Wigner D-matrix by applying sparse rotation operations to a provided identity matrix.

  • eye (Tensor) – Identity matrix of shape (dim, dim). Device and dtype are inferred.

  • alpha (Optional[Tensor]) – Alpha Euler angle.

  • beta (Optional[Tensor]) – Beta Euler angle.

  • gamma (Optional[Tensor]) – Gamma Euler angle.

  • sincos_alpha (Optional[Tensor]) – Precomputed sin/cos for alpha angle.

  • sincos_beta (Optional[Tensor]) – Precomputed sin/cos for beta angle.

  • sincos_gamma (Optional[Tensor]) – Precomputed sin/cos for gamma angle.

  • info (WignerRotationInfo) – Precomputed sparse rotation info.

equitorch.nn.functional.align_to_z_wigner_d(eye: Tensor, xyz: Tensor, max_m: int, info: WignerRotationInfo, normalized: bool = True, eps: float = 1e-14) → Tensor

Computes Wigner D-matrix \(D(R_{align})\) that rotates vector \(\vec{v}\) to z-axis.

Functional version of AlignToZWignerD.

See the class for more details.

The rotation \(R_{align}\) is \((0, -\theta, -\phi)\) where \(\theta, \phi\) are polar and azimuthal angles of \(\vec{v}\).

Parameters:

  • eye (torch.Tensor) – Identity matrix of shape (dim, dim).

  • xyz (torch.Tensor) – Input Cartesian coordinates, shape (..., 3).

  • max_m (int) – Maximum m value for sincos calculation, derived from irreps.

  • info (WignerRotationInfo) – Precomputed sparse rotation info for the irreps.

  • normalized (bool, optional) – Whether xyz is already normalized. Defaults to True.

  • eps (float, optional) – Epsilon for numerical stability. Defaults to 1e-14.

Returns:

Dense Wigner D-matrix for alignment, shape (..., dim, dim).

Return type:

torch.Tensor

equitorch.nn.functional.gating(input: Tensor, gates: Tensor, irreps_info: IrrepsInfo) → Tensor

Equivariant gating mechanism.

Applies element-wise gates to features. This is the functional version of the Gate module.

See Gate for more details on the gating mechanism, including how input and gates are structured and combined.

Parameters:

  • input (torch.Tensor) – Tensor to be gated. Shape (..., irreps.dim, channels).

  • gates (torch.Tensor) – Gating values. Shape depends on how gates are applied (e.g., (..., num_gates, channels) for irrep-wise gating or (..., 1, channels) for global gating).

  • irreps_info (IrrepsInfo) – Contains irreps_info.irrep_index, which maps each component of input’s spherical dimension to an index in gates’ corresponding dimension (the gate dimension).

Returns:

The gated input tensor, shape (..., irreps.dim, channels).

Return type:

torch.Tensor

This is the functional version of the irrep-wise mode of the Dropout module. See Dropout for more details on the dropout mechanism when irrep_wise=True.

  • training (bool) – Apply dropout if True.

  • irreps_info (IrrepsInfo) – Contains irreps structure information, such as irreps_info.irrep_index to map components of input to their respective irrep instances, and irreps_info.num_irreps. Must not be None.
